tour_stop.post_content: This unusual wood-sided home, constructed ca.1900, is a wonderful example of a one-story Craftsman Bungalow with Folk Victorian styling. In its relative simplicity and small scale, it is a clear departure from the surrounding grand homes that were being built in large numbers on the East End. Above the full front porch is a cross-gabled roof with symmetrical twin peaks and round vent openings that frame the front facade. Other interesting architectural details include wood porch railings, simple Doric columns, and distinctive ceramic chimney pots that crown two of three chimneys.

This unusual two-story apartment building was constructed around 1930. Situated on a narrow lot and surrounded mainly by single-family residences, this interesting property exhibits a classic geometric appearance of the Art Deco style that flourished from 1920 to 1940. Constructed of red brick with a center entrance tower and a side patio, it bears little ornamentation and has a flat roof, two symmetrical second-floor balconies, comer casement windows and horizontal banding. A first floor bay window was a later addition.

Built in the Colonial Revival style, this handsome two and a half story buff brick residence features a side-gabled roof with two dormer windows. A series of prominent speculators owned the property before the current house was built, including J.E. Chamberlain, John Q. & Mary Dickinson, Joseph & Helen Schwabe and Sam Silverstein.

Built in the Colonial Revival style, this handsome two and a half story buff brick residence features a side-gabled roof with two dormer windows. A series of prominent speculators owned the property before the current house was built, including J.E. Chamberlain, John Q. & Mary Dickinson, Joseph & Helen Schwabe and Sam Silverstein.

This stately three-story brick apartment complex features an eclectic combination of Spanish and Colonial Revival elements, including a red tile roof, decorative bracket molding, arch windows and portico.

This charming two-story stucco Tudor Revival home with eclectic characteristics was built ca. 1925. Among the interesting elements of this quaint residence are the steep cross gabled roof, prominent stucco chimney, detailed half timbering, and a large vertical prismatic window above the front entrance. Though its origin is not documented, these features and other trademark details are reminiscent of the work of Charlestonian John C. Norman, Sr., who in 1922 became the seventh licensed architect in West Virginia (which began licensing architects in 1921), and the second registered African American architect in the state -- (Huntington architect R.E.L. Washington was the first).

This two-story Colonial Revival residence was built ca.1930 as a multi-unit apartment complex. Rectangular in shape with a symmetrical exterior, the property has a unique recessed front entrance at ground level with a corresponding covered stairwell at the second level. On the exterior, the property is buff brick with prominent multi-paned wooden windows flanking the center doorway and stairs on both levels. A green tile roof covers the front portion of the building, and a flat roof covers the main portion. The property was sold in 2000. In a rare undertaking, the owners reversed the usual order of things and changed the building from its original function as a multi-unit apartment complex into a single-family residence.

This flat-roofed brick building at Elizabeth and Washington Sts. features two recessed storefronts with Z-brick facades. Originally thought to be a restaurant or delicatessen, between 1935 and 1941 this building was home to Blossom Dairy, a chain of local dairy stores that featured classic Art Deco styling and served up the famous "Mammoth Milkshake" (Blossom Dairy's "Super Store No. 7" opened in 1941 at 904 Quarrier St., where it remains in total Art Deco splendor). Spence Paint Company moved into 1600 Washington St. in 1941 and remained until its closure over 50 years later. After sitting vacant for a time, the building changed hands in 2005. The new owners have tirelessly rehabilitated it, exposing the original pressed tin ceiling on the interior, converting the second floor to artist's studios and adding new exterior awnings. Now, this once busy commercial corner has come back to life, wonderfully transformed into a very popular local eatery called "Bluegrass Kitchen". This flat-roofed brick building at Elizabeth and Washington Sts. features two recessed storefronts with Z-brick facades. Originally thought to be a restaurant or delicatessen, between 1935 and 1941 this building was home to Blossom Dairy, a chain of local dairy stores that featured classic Art Deco styling and served up the famous "Mammoth Milkshake" (Blossom Dairy's "Super Store No. 7" opened in 1941 at 904 Quarrier St., where it remains in total Art Deco splendor). Spence Paint Company moved into 1600 Washington St. in 1941 and remained until its closure over 50 years later. After sitting vacant for a time, the building changed hands in 2005. The new owners have tirelessly rehabilitated it, exposing the original pressed tin ceiling on the interior, converting the second floor to artist's studios and adding new exterior awnings. Now, this once busy commercial corner has come back to life, wonderfully transformed into a very popular local eatery called "Bluegrass Kitchen".

This lovely cut stone and brick property is a variation on the popular early 20th century Craftsman Bungalow residential style. Built ca. 1905, it features a combination gable and hip roof, projecting eaves accented with brackets, front and side dormers, a stone porch balustrade and intricate stonework. Owned by the First Church of Christian Scientist since 1973 and currently operated as the Christian Science Sunday School, the property was originally built for Dr. Hugh D. Nicholson and his wife Roberta. Nicholson was a physician who obtained his medical degree in Richmond, Va. in 1897 and came to West Virginia to work at the Sheltering Arms Hospital located in Hansford, Kanawha Co. Except for the exterior being painted several times, the property remains virtually unchanged.

tour_stop.post_title: All Together Now by Jeff Pierson

tour_stop.post_content: This distinctive apartment building, constructed ca.1930, is one of Charleston's finest examples of residential Art Moderne architecture. The front elevation is a unique combination of materials, with cut stone surrounding the first floor entrance and brick on the second story. Adorned with classic Art Modeme features, the building includes a flat roof with a small ledge at the roofline, casement/comer windows and horizontally-oriented metal balustrades. Although rare as a residential type in Charleston, it proved to be a pragmatic choice for homeowners because it was relatively easy and economical to build. Art Moderne design was highlighted at the 1933 World's Fair and became a popular building style nationwide before World War II that evoked a feeling of technological advancement, streamlined high speed transportation, and innovative new construction techniques.

This rather simple Federal style home with Victorian elements was built in 1834 by Augustus Ruffner and his wife Mary Elizabeth. Augustus was the fourth son of prominent saltmaker Daniel Ruffner who built "Holly Grove" at 1710 Kanawha Blvd., and the grandson of area pioneer Joseph Ruffner. The Ruffners were among the first to develop the area's salt lands, which brought the family considerable wealth and placed them at the forefront of local society. A cultivated man who owned a lumber mill on Elk River, Augustus named his riverfront home "Cedar Grove" for the preponderance of cedar trees that surrounded it. Among the oldest surviving residences in Charleston, Cedar Grove has a pitched gable roof with a one-story porch, tall double-hung windows, fancy entryway, ornate woodwork and decorative brackets. The house remained in the Ruffner family until it was purchased by Margaret North in the 1940s. Although now dwarfed by surrounding development and carefully adapted to office use, it remains one of Charleston's most significant early homes.

Charleston's Orthodox Jewish community was organized in the 1890s by Eastern European immigrants who held services in private homes and later in a rented hall. In 1908 the congregation purchased the former State (Lee) Street Methodist Church and used it for services until 1949, when the present B'nai Jacob Synagogue was built. A national demand for new synagogues after World War II created a building boom of modem community centers designed to serve a variety of social, educational and religious needs. In keeping with this trend, B'nai Jacob cast off traditional European styles and embraced the new architectural form featuring Art Deco and Modernist elements that meld with the vernacular corpus of the building. Those architectural details form a solid surround for a spectacular series of six stunning stained glass panels that grace the entryway. Designed by local artist David Pushkin, the windows display representative symbolism from the Torah. They give an interpretation of the Creation story, one window for each of the six days named by the artist: Light, Firmament, Seeds, Luminaries, Living Soul, and Let Us Make Man; the work in its entirety represents the seventh day. In Hebrew tradition, the windows are properly viewed on the inside from the right to left. To fully appreciate their fine artistry, visitors are invited to step inside the synagogue and view them on a clear day. They may be seen on arrangement by calling (304) 346-4722.

Built in 1910 for Charles Capito, this elegant NeoClassical Revival home features a dominant front portico topped by massive Ionic columns and flanked by symmetrical pavilion-like kiosks on either side. Capito came to Charleston as a young man involved in the grocery and vegetable trade, and later became a liquor wholesaler. In 1877 he married Sophia Benz and they had four children. Active in area business and industry, Charles became president of Kanawha National Bank in 1910 when he built this spacious residence. Mter serving as headquarters of the Central West Virginia Chapter of the American Red Cross for over 30 years, the Capito House returned to private ownership in 2004. The new owner has meticulously restored the property for use as office space, and added a modem, architecturally compatible garage at the rear of the property.

This attractive 2Y2 story home exhibits the vernacular Prairie Style form featuring a symmetrical facade, red tile roof with crowning finials, a large full-width front porch with flanking stone columns and three arched windows at the center peak. By far the most distinguishing characteristic is its solid stone construction, a unique aspect in a neighborhood dominated by wood frame residences. David R. Isaac and his wife Ann constructed the house around 1914. David~s father, John Isaac, was born in Wales where he learned the stonecutter's trade before migrating to the U.S. in 1869. Eventually settling in West Virginia as a stone mason for the C&O Railroad, it is said he built the first coke ovens at Quinnimont in Fayette Co. Born in 1873 in Fayette Co., David R. Isaac entered the stone business early in life and became an expert mason prior to establishing the Cut Stone Co. on nearby Lewis St. in 1906 with his cousin, George R. Isaac. As manager of the successful enterprise, David was responsible for building numerous area landmarks, including Bream Memorial Church (317-19 Washington St. West) and the 1908 mausoleum at Charleston's Spring Hill Cemetery Park.

This unusual wood-sided home, constructed ca.1900, is a wonderful example of a one-story Craftsman Bungalow with Folk Victorian styling. In its relative simplicity and small scale, it is a clear departure from the surrounding grand homes that were being built in large numbers on the East End. Above the full front porch is a cross-gabled roof with symmetrical twin peaks and round vent openings that frame the front facade. Other interesting architectural details include wood porch railings, simple Doric columns, and distinctive ceramic chimney pots that crown two of three chimneys.

This unusual two-story apartment building was constructed around 1930. Situated on a narrow lot and surrounded mainly by single-family residences, this interesting property exhibits a classic geometric appearance of the Art Deco style that flourished from 1920 to 1940. Constructed of red brick with a center entrance tower and a side patio, it bears little ornamentation and has a flat roof, two symmetrical second-floor balconies, comer casement windows and horizontal banding. A first floor bay window was a later addition.

Built in the Colonial Revival style, this handsome two and a half story buff brick residence features a side-gabled roof with two dormer windows. A series of prominent speculators owned the property before the current house was built, including J.E. Chamberlain, John Q. & Mary Dickinson, Joseph & Helen Schwabe and Sam Silverstein.

Built in the Colonial Revival style, this handsome two and a half story buff brick residence features a side-gabled roof with two dormer windows. A series of prominent speculators owned the property before the current house was built, including J.E. Chamberlain, John Q. & Mary Dickinson, Joseph & Helen Schwabe and Sam Silverstein.

This stately three-story brick apartment complex features an eclectic combination of Spanish and Colonial Revival elements, including a red tile roof, decorative bracket molding, arch windows and portico.

Among the interesting elements of this quaint residence are the steep cross gabled roof, prominent stucco chimney, detailed half timbering, and a large vertical prismatic window above the front entrance. Though its origin is not documented, these features and other trademark details are reminiscent of the work of Charlestonian John C. Norman, Sr., who in 1922 became the seventh licensed architect in West Virginia (which began licensing architects in 1921), and the second registered African American architect in the state -- (Huntington architect R.E.L. Washington was the first).

This two-story Colonial Revival residence was built ca.1930 as a multi-unit apartment complex. Rectangular in shape with a symmetrical exterior, the property has a unique recessed front entrance at ground level with a corresponding covered stairwell at the second level. On the exterior, the property is buff brick with prominent multi-paned wooden windows flanking the center doorway and stairs on both levels. A green tile roof covers the front portion of the building, and a flat roof covers the main portion. The property was sold in 2000. In a rare undertaking, the owners reversed the usual order of things and changed the building from its original function as a multi-unit apartment complex into a single-family residence.

Spence Paint Company moved into 1600 Washington St. in 1941 and remained until its closure over 50 years later. After sitting vacant for a time, the building changed hands in 2005. The new owners have tirelessly rehabilitated it, exposing the original pressed tin ceiling on the interior, converting the second floor to artist's studios and adding new exterior awnings. Now, this once busy commercial corner has come back to life, wonderfully transformed into a very popular local eatery called "Bluegrass Kitchen". Originally thought to be a restaurant or delicatessen, between 1935 and 1941 this building was home to Blossom Dairy, a chain of local dairy stores that featured classic Art Deco styling and served up the famous "Mammoth Milkshake" (Blossom Dairy's "Super Store No. 7" opened in 1941 at 904 Quarrier St., where it remains in total Art Deco splendor). Now, this once busy commercial corner has come back to life, wonderfully transformed into a very popular local eatery called "Bluegrass Kitchen".

Owned by the First Church of Christian Scientist since 1973 and currently operated as the Christian Science Sunday School, the property was originally built for Dr. Hugh D. Nicholson and his wife Roberta. Except for the exterior being painted several times, the property remains virtually unchanged.

Among the oldest surviving residences in Charleston, Cedar Grove has a pitched gable roof with a one-story porch, tall double-hung windows, fancy entryway, ornate woodwork and decorative brackets. The house remained in the Ruffner family until it was purchased by Margaret North in the 1940s. Although now dwarfed by surrounding development and carefully adapted to office use, it remains one of Charleston's most significant early homes.

In keeping with this trend, B'nai Jacob cast off traditional European styles and embraced the new architectural form featuring Art Deco and Modernist elements that meld with the vernacular corpus of the building. Those architectural details form a solid surround for a spectacular series of six stunning stained glass panels that grace the entryway. They give an interpretation of the Creation story, one window for each of the six days named by the artist: Light, Firmament, Seeds, Luminaries, Living Soul, and Let Us Make Man; the work in its entirety represents the seventh day. In Hebrew tradition, the windows are properly viewed on the inside from the right to left. To fully appreciate their fine artistry, visitors are invited to step inside the synagogue and view them on a clear day. They may be seen on arrangement by calling (304) 346-4722.

Capito came to Charleston as a young man involved in the grocery and vegetable trade, and later became a liquor wholesaler. In 1877 he married Sophia Benz and they had four children. Active in area business and industry, Charles became president of Kanawha National Bank in 1910 when he built this spacious residence. Mter serving as headquarters of the Central West Virginia Chapter of the American Red Cross for over 30 years, the Capito House returned to private ownership in 2004. The new owner has meticulously restored the property for use as office space, and added a modem, architecturally compatible garage at the rear of the property.

This attractive 2Y2 story home exhibits the vernacular Prairie Style form featuring a symmetrical facade, red tile roof with crowning finials, a large full-width front porch with flanking stone columns and three arched windows at the center peak. By far the most distinguishing characteristic is its solid stone construction, a unique aspect in a neighborhood dominated by wood frame residences. David R. Isaac and his wife Ann constructed the house around 1914. David~s father, John Isaac, was born in Wales where he learned the stonecutter's trade before migrating to the U.S. in 1869. Eventually settling in West Virginia as a stone mason for the C&O Railroad, it is said he built the first coke ovens at Quinnimont in Fayette Co. Born in 1873 in Fayette Co., David R. Isaac entered the stone business early in life and became an expert mason prior to establishing the Cut Stone Co. on nearby Lewis St. in 1906 with his cousin, George R. Isaac. As manager of the successful enterprise, David was responsible for building numerous area landmarks, including Bream Memorial Church (317-19 Washington St. West) and the 1908 mausoleum at Charleston's Spring Hill Cemetery Park.

Charleston's First Christian Church congregation was organized in 1890. The church (also known as the Disciples of Christ) was founded in the early 1800s in the United States. Seeking to move beyond denominational disagreements, the founders envisioned a united church modeled on the New Testament. Among them was Alexander Campbell of Bethany, W.Va., who had established Bethany College in 1840. After first meeting in the old Charleston Baptist Church at Donnally and Laidley Sts. and then in a building at Lee and Brooks Sts., church trustees in 1917 bought the present site from H.D. Ruffner for $11 ,500. When construction of the basement was completed in 1922, the congregation moved into it as work proceeded on the present structure. Built at a cost of $104,500, the imposing two-story stucco and brick Spanish Colonial Revival building was dedicated in 1927. It remained a house of worship until the Kanawha Players purchased it in 2005 as its headquarters and theater. Interesting exterior details include one-story wings that flank the center nave, a large, round rose stained glass window on the front facade and three arcaded arches resting on stucco piers.
tour_stop.address: Washington St E & Beauregard St, Charleston, WV

tour_stop.post_content: This vernacular Folk Victorian residence with Colonial influences was constructed ca. 1895 by Gen. Edward Langley Wood and wife Nannie. Highlighted by a low-pitched slate roof, two sided portico supported by 10 Doric columns, wood shutters, an elliptical fanlight and sidelights framing the entryway, the property is surrounded by a white picket fence that evokes the appearance of a rural farmhouse. Edward L. Wood was born in Kanawha Co. in 1846. Although Wood's family moved to Ohio when he was young, Edward returned to Charleston in 1869 where he studied for the bar, but never actually practiced law. Instead, he became state librarian in 1875 and adjutant general the following year, a post he held for several years. After retiring from public life, Wood was appointed sergeant-at-arms of the W.Va. House of Delegates in 1911 (the honorary title of "General" came from his service in this capacity).

This classic Colonial brick home with gray slate roof was built in 1903 for prominent coal and lumber operator Henry Clay Dickinson and his wife Margaret. Designed and constructed by local contractors Warden & Wood, the exterior features a center portico with semi-circular balustrade and Ionic columns. To the rear of the expansive lot is a carriage or stable house that echoes the colonial features of the house. In 1941, noted local architect Ludwig T. Bengston remodeled the interior that still retains its original stained glass windows and oak trim.

This imposing three-story dwelling was designed by prominent local architect H. Rus Warne in 1904 for local banker and coal operator J.C. Morrison. Unquestionably one of the city's grandest examples of English Tudor Revival architecture, it is a classic blend of brick construction and half-timber ornamentation centered on a large lot. Reminiscent of the second generation of grand homes built on the East End between 1900 and 1920, when Charleston's population grew from 12,000 to 40,000 residents, the Morrison House embodies a break from Victorian influences and the rise of new architectural expression. As with many grand old Charleston homes, the property was divided into apartments in later years.

This two and a half story eclectic Victorian residence was built ca. 1903 by John and Wayland Davidson for John and Frances Carver. The house contains several noteworthy elements, including a semi-circular vestibule with Ionic columns topped by wrought iron railings, an arched front door, leaded tracery windows and flanking dormers. Although the interior has been altered, the exterior retains much of its original character. A coal operator, John Carver emigrated from Wales and moved to Charleston around 1877. Along with brothers Enoch and James, he operated Carver Brothers Coal Co. John died at the age of 70 in 1912, while Enoch (who resided at 1416 Kanawha Blvd.) was killed in a tragic mine explosion in 1915. Family fortunes waned during the Depression and the stately brick residence was sold at a trustee's sale in 1937. The structure is now leased as commercial office space.

Occupying nearly 10 acres at the southern edge of the old Kanawha & Michigan rail line that formerly serviced the city's warehouse and industrial district, Kanawha Manufacturing Company is one of the largest manufacturing facilities in Charleston. Founded in 1902 as Kanawha Mine Car Company to produce mine cars for the southern West Virginia coal fields and renamed Kanawha Manufacturing in 1915, the company has greatly broadened its operations to a variety of products for the mining, chemical and other significant industries. Now specializing in carbon and stainless steel fabrication and machining, the sprawling complex includes machine, structural and forge shops, a foundry and supplemental buildings. Adjacent to the office building stands an interesting stone monument erected by the company in honor of its employees who have served in the U.S. armed services.

This massive brick house is an eclectic combination of Tudor Revival and Spanish Revival architecture. With 13 rooms, 7 bathrooms and 53 windows and straddling a large comer lot at Quarrier & Elizabeth streets, it is a dominating property. Prominent area banker John C. Malone built the house ca. 1920, and sold it to coal operator and entrepreneur William G. Caperton (uncle to former W.Va. governor Gaston Caperton) and his wife Katherine in 1928. The Capertons gained a considerable reputation for lavish parties and wedding receptions that often included liquor during Prohibition. Charles Newland obtained the house in 1940 and sold it in 1947 to Sadie Tweel, who owned a confectionary on Lee Street. Tweel's granddaughter was child star Anissa Jones, better known as "Buffy" on the popular 1960s TV sitcom, Family Affair. As a young girl, Anissa spent several summers here. Over the years the property has been a law office, union headquarters, and a rooming house. In the 1970s, a female boarder shot dead a man on the porch who had accused her of stealing his wallet. In the 1980s the property was meticulously restored to its former glory as a private residence. The current owners purchased the property in 1992 and maintain it in exquisite condition. Of special interest is the home's unusual address "1599A Quarrier St." which came about because the neighboring house (1599) was originally the last residence in the 1500 block of Quarrier St. When the property owners later split their comer lot and sold off a portion for construction of another house, the new residents faced a dilemma. With no whole numbers available for the new home, their address became 1599A Quarrier St.

This charming six-unit Tudor Revival residential development sits on a rustic park-like cul-de-sac. Built ca. 1922 by local architect Frederick Crowther, a native of England, Manor Place is a sensitive composition of urban design that recalls an English cottage in a suburban garden setting. Each of the units reflects an excellence in scale and perspective, replete with half-timbered walls and English tiled, dormered roofs. Interior spaces feature compact airy spaces resulting from wellplaced bay windows and shed dormers. Frederick Crowther designed other revival-style residences in the city, including several in South Hills that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places. He moved to Detroit in 1927, where he became a respected architectural illustrator until his death in 1955.

This eclectic brick house is an example of early twentieth century transitional architecture. The large two-story portico and side porch supported by paired Ionic columns exhibit Neo-Classical Revival influences, while the large mullion stained glass window and dark interior oak woodwork are typically late Victorian. The house was built in 1907 for Solomon & Bettie Hilburn Meyers, both originally from Germany. Solomon, who owned a plumbing, heating and gas fitting business in Charleston, served with distinction in the Confederate lOth Va. Cavalry during the Civil War. Wounded four times in combat, he remained an unreconstructed rebel who never took the oath of allegiance. The Meyers had four children and were active members of the Hebrew Temple in Charleston. Two sons, Samuel H. & Alexander, carried on the family business under the name Meyers Brothers. Dr. Peter Haley and his wife Mary Alice bought the home from Alexander Meyers in 1952 and owned it until1983. Dr. Haley operated his medical practice in the basement of the home. Area residents are quick to point out the former entrance to the clinic that can still be seen on the Ruffner Ave. side of the house.

Volunteers from the East End Main Street Design Committee commissioned Charleston artist Rob Cleland to paint this public arts mural in the summer of 2006. Located on the eastern (Elizabeth St. side) of 1599 Washington St. East, "Out & About" is 19/ x 31/ and took a little over a month to complete. The kick-off was a children's mini-mural painting party held during Charleston's FestivALL. From this, the artist was able to draw influences of indiscriminate color usage and the free flow of design. The commission was to capture the diversity and "flavor" of the East End. Most agree this is a successful representation of this lively and colorful community.

Built in 1922 and opened in 1923 as a neighborhood junior high school to educate seventh through ninth grade students, this handsome institutional structure was named for Theodore Roosevelt (1858-1919), the nation's 26th president. Three stories in height and built of wire cut brick with limestone comers and trim, its interior hallways contain terrazzo floors and salt glazed brick wainscoting with wood floor classrooms. Whereas other historic city junior high schools -- including Lincoln and Woodrow Wilson on the West Side and Thomas Jefferson on the East End-have been felled by the wrecking ball, Roosevelt endures. The city's oldest continuously operated junior high when it closed at the end of the 1999-2000 school year, this rare surviving example of early 20th century public school architecture has been successfully converted into the Roosevelt Neighborhood Center and also houses a detachment of the Charleston Police Department.

John B. Ruby and C.H. Sterrett formed the Ruby-Sterrett Motor Co. in 1919. Two years later they obtained the exclusive Packard auto dealership for 17 West Virginia counties. In 1927, local architect Charles Havilland constructed this elegant two-story brick building to house sales and display rooms for new cars and a large service department. Noteworthy details include a stone cornice, stone pilasters with human face carvings on the ends, and an elaborate stone frontispiece with a distinctive broken-pediment Federal entrance. Sharp-eyed observers will notice a tangible reminder of the past in the faint ghost outline of PACKARD that remains above the front entrance. This unique building managed to survive and continued to house a series of luxury car dealerships in an essentially residential area until the 1970s. Currently, a law firm owns and occupies the unusual space.

Built on speculation in 1836 as one of two identical properties by builder Norris Whitteker, its first owners were Henry and Julia MacFarland. Acquired in tum by the Ruby, Crowley and Hubbard families, the two-story brick residence is regarded as one the finest examples of Greek Revival architecture in Charleston. Its long history includes taking a direct hit from a cannonball (displayed inside the house) during the September 1862 Battle of Charleston when the Confederates briefly occupied the Kanawha Valley; the house also served as a hospital during the Civil War. Now carefully restored and adapted for office use, the house may be visited during frequent public events or by arrangement with the West Virginia Humanities Council [(304)346-8500].

Charleston's oldest municipal park, this somber but elegant grove of ancient trees stands on the original site of the Ruffner Family cemetery. Large flat stones at the west corner of the property mark the graves of Joseph Ruffner, who once owned much of the area covered by this guide, his wife, and the wife of one of his sons, Daniel. The stones are by tradition eastward-facing, and there seems to be an error in the inscriptions. Daniel is cited as the seventh son on his wife's stone, but is shown as the fifth son & sixth child on his parent's stone. The Ruffners deeded the area to the city for use as a municipal cemetery, with the provision that one 35' x 45' corner remain the burial plot of its Ruffner occupants in perpetuity. After the city later tried to break the covenant, the Ruffner descendants opposed the move and prevailed in a W.Va. Supreme Court decision. A 1917 map of the park shows over 100 gravesites, but it is unknown whether they remain. Some claim the generally raised elevation indicates a layer of fill over the old graves, while others say the remains were moved to the city's current municipal burial ground, Spring Hill Cemetery, located on the hills north of town.

This interesting pair of homes was built in 1923 for sisters Claire (1612) and Hedwig (1614) Schwabe by their father Albert, a prominent local merchant. They embody the Italian Renaissance Revival style, cube-shaped with a balanced, symmetrical fac;ade, flanking columns, arched openings and balconies. With an aura of Eastern European influence, the houses are mirror images with their main entrances facing each other across a central walk. Claire Schwabe never married, but Hedwig married into the May family, thus cementing a wholesale and retail clothing partnership first formed in 1878 by Isadore Schwabe and Solomon May. Schwabe-May, a trade name that still stands for fine accoutrements, remains in business not far from the original store on Capitol Street in downtown Charleston.

An outstanding example of Spanish Revival architecture, the Scott-Abney house was built in 1906 and features a stucco facade, arch windows, Spanish tile roof and a prominent portico with arched entrance. The first owner of this property was A.B. Weaver, treasurer of Mountain City Lumber Co., and his wife Nannie. In 1909, 65-year old Addison M. Scott and his 29-year old wife Florence Jeroloman Scott, daughter of New York City Judge John Jeroloman, purchased the property. A prominent civil engineer who came to Charleston in 1873 with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Scott supervised the installation of the nation's first Chanoine-style movable wicket dam on the Kanawha River. Mter retiring in 1901, Scott managed his real estate holdings and engaged in public service activities.

The St. Paul congregation was established in Charleston in 1892. Between 1914 and 1916 this handsome cruciform Gothic style church was built of Indiana limestone. Enhanced with stone parapets and window tracery, this distinctive house of worship was designed by Weber, Werner and Adkins, a Cincinnati architectural firm that also designed the Security Building at the comer of Capitol & Virginia Sts. in downtown Charleston in 1915.
tour_stop.address: Beauregard and Lee St, Charleston, WV

tour_stop.post_content: The St. Paul congregation was established in Charleston in 1892. Between 1914 and 1916 this handsome cruciform Gothic style church was built of Indiana limestone. Enhanced with stone parapets and window tracery, this distinctive house of worship was designed by Weber, Werner and Adkins, a Cincinnati architectural firm that also designed the Security Building at the comer of Capitol & Virginia Sts. in downtown Charleston in 1915.
tour_stop.address: Beauregard and Lee St, Charleston, WV

tour_stop.post_content: Samuel and Cynthia Stephenson built this home at a time when Bradford Street formed the eastern limits of Charleston. Born in Nicholas County in 1859, Samuel moved to Charleston and pursued a career in the oil, gas and coal industries. He also served as a state deputy revenue collector and city councilman. Built ca. 1889, this distinctive Queen Anne style residence is one of the most ornate and distinctive properties on the East End. The house, which has been immaculately restored and painted in an appropriately polychromatic palette, features classic Victorian detailing with a comer turret, patterned slate roof, raised chimney pots, and intricate wood siding typical of a "Painted Lady" of the Victorian era.

The Charleston Woman's Club House is an outstanding example of French Chateauesque architecture. Designed by local architect Walter F. Martens, whose plan won a design competition, this prominent landmark was dedicated in 1929 and features symmetrically placed wings and a steeply pitched slate roof. Its entrance is embellished with wrought iron detailing, a trademark of the architect. Walter F. Martens designed over a dozen buildings on the East End, including the 1925 Georgian-style West Virginia Governor's Mansion located at 1716 Kanawha Blvd.

tour_stop.post_title: All Together Now by Jeff Pierson
